channel.title: Tutorial 3: case Keyword
channel.description:
[center][b]Tutorial 3: case Keyword[/b][/center]
[b]Java vs C++[/b] The case keyword does the same thing in Java as in C and C++;it labels a branch inside a [i]switch[/i] statement.
[b]Syntax[/b] The keyword turns a statement into a labeled statement.
[code]case constant_integer_expression: statement[/code] Within a [i]switch[/i] statement, if the test value matches [i]constant_integer_expression[/i], execution transfers to [i]statement[/i](unless another branch was taken first).
[b]Example[/b] The [i]case[/i] keyword is only a label and not a control structure. This is why execution falls through unless you use [i]break[/i].In the following example, [i]break[/i] prevents falling through to the default case. [code]switch(c) { case 'a': case 'e': case 'i': case 'o': case 'u': is_a_vowel = true; break; default: is_a_vowel = false; }[/code]
Thank you for reading my third Java tutorial,more to come soon.

[quote=“frank_, post:2, topic:222060”]what is a switch statement?
what is default?

i wouldnt have half a clue what this post was about unless i already knew java (or any other c based language)[/quote]

I agree with Frank_, if you can’t explain everything in your tutorials then don’t bother posting them.

Unhandled:

Why can’t you switch strings in Java?

It might be a possibility in Java 7.

item.title: Tutorial 3: case Keyword
item.dc:creator: @Java_Duke Java Duke
item.description:
@Java_Duke wrote:

[center]Tutorial 3: case Keyword[/center]

Java vs C++
The case keyword does the same thing in Java as in C and C++;it labels a branch inside a switch statement.

Syntax
The keyword turns a statement into a labeled statement.

case constant_integer_expression: statement
Within a switch statement, if the test value matches constant_integer_expression, execution transfers to statement(unless another branch was taken first).

Example
The case keyword is only a label and not a control structure. This is why execution falls through unless you use break.In the following example, break prevents falling through to the default case.

switch(c) { case 'a': case 'e': case 'i': case 'o': case 'u': is_a_vowel = true; break; default: is_a_vowel = false; }

Thank you for reading my third Java tutorial,more to come soon.
